body:
Do not worry, this is a reoccurring temporary issue on builds.apache.org. I created a infrastructure ticket for this: https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/INFRA-11238

If you like you can force push (`push -f`), to give it another try.

Modified the commit to be a little more inline with what had suggested on the dev list.  It was less code to use a private holder class to do the lazy init (even if not strictly needed for thread safety).  If the other style is preferred I'll change it to use a static check and set method for the static field.  What do you think @blackdrag ?
Thanks!

> I added some missing subprojects to the .gitignore file. That's the quick & easy solution. I'd actually prefer ignoring .classpath, .project and .settings globally without hard coding all subprojects into .gitignore. Any opinions?

I agree.

> Additionally I reverted the default task, so that gradle shows its generic helpful "splash screen" when being invoked without parameters. Was there a particular reason for the wrapper regeneration being the default task? If so maybe we could comment that with a one liner.

no idea, but I agree it should not be the default

I think the CI failure is not related to my changes.

```
FAILURE: Build failed with an exception.

* What went wrong:
Unable to start the daemon process.
This problem might be caused by incorrect configuration of the daemon.
For example, an unrecognized jvm option is used.
Please refer to the user guide chapter on the daemon at https://docs.gradle.org/2.11/userguide/gradle_daemon.html
Please read the following process output to find out more:
-----------------------
Picked up JAVA_TOOL_OPTIONS: -Dfile.encoding=UTF-8
Please use CMSClassUnloadingEnabled in place of CMSPermGenSweepingEnabled in the future
*** Error in `/home/jenkins/jenkins-slave/tools/hudson.model.JDK/latest1.6/bin/java': free(): invalid next size (fast): 0x00007fefe0c06be0 ***
```

Yes, the failure is not caused by your changes. It's a reoccurring temporary issue on builds.apache.org. There is an unsolved infrastructure issue for this: https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/INFRA-11238
Thanks!

the commit is ok, but it could have been a smaller one, if I look at your changes in line 1600 and following. Same for the xor parts, the old logic could have stayed, only the following line with == was really wrong here. You also don't really need to check for == to avoid a call to equalIncludingGenerics, the method will do that check anyway. Where it does makes sense, is of course in the upper bounds check, because they can be null now, thus you need to check or else you cannot get the length (you know that of course, it is just for a third party reader)

Yes, as I wrote in my earlier comment, I took the opportunity of the fix to make the code a bit more regular and consistent: the lower and upper bounds are compared in a similar way, itself similar to the way the generic types are compared in the second method (replace "upper" by "gt" and the blocks are identical), and the use of `^` is generalized (I introduced it in a previous PR). I felt it made the code easier to understand.

The `lower1 != lower2` check protecting the `equalIncludingGenerics` call is indeed useless and can be removed to simplify.

However, I can also definitely limit the change to removing the `lower1 == lower2` shortcut if you'd rather keep the change as small as possible. I think the code is more brittle (and a bit less readable) as it is -- you couldn't swap the lower and upper bounds checks as they are if you wanted to, for example, because of the `upper1 == upper2` shortcut which would become as incorrect as `lower1 == lower2` currently is -- but it certainly works. I just mean my change is not purely a style change.

Hopefully we can release 2.4.6 soon, but before we do we should fix this issue.

@ everybody: Should we apply this fix, or rollback the original change?
created https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/GROOVY-7755 to track this
created https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/GROOVY-7756 to track this
CI failure seems to be unrelated to my changes

Yes, the failure is an unrelated reoccurring temporary issue on builds.apache.org. There is an unsolved ticket for this: https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/INFRA-11238

I also set up travis ci to build pull requests, in the hope that it's more stable than builds.apache.org.

If you like you can force push (push -f), to give it another try.

I don't feel confident enough in this area of the code to say this fix is good.  So unless others agree it's a good fix the best option may be to revert the original change.  

As @shils and @fpavageau have pointed out, I haven't correctly captured the reason for the failure in naming the test.  It almost seems to be related to Extension methods, and in this case the return type being from the DefaultGroovyMethods.
+1 for reverting https://github.com/apache/groovy/commit/fae29119a1102393ae5d1645c3fc1e06547b0ad8 prior to 2.4.6 and creating an issue to revisit it in the future.
Thanks! :+1:
Thanks! :+1:
Thanks!
Do you see a reason to prefer a category here over an extension module?

If I put entries in the map, even if I set them to the default value, I would expect to be able to iterate over them using methods such as `keySet()/entrySet()`.  However that would no longer work with this change in place.

Hello @jwagenleitner :)

I agree, that's what I would expect in case of a normal map also.
But I would also expect `containsKey` to return `false`, if I haven't inserted anything, but that's not the current behavior.

``` Groovy
def x = [:].withDefault {0}
println x.containsKey(1) // false
println x[1]             // 0
println x.containsKey(1) // true
```

Therefore I think this new behavior is consistent with the class.

If you don't agree, I have a few alternative ideas, like:
- `removeIfDefault(Object)` // removes current key, if value is equal to default
- `consolidate()` // removes all default values
- constructor parameter `STORE_DEFAULT storeDefaultValues = STORE_DEFAULT.FALSE`

ps. this change might imply that `containsKey` should rather return whether the value is equal to the default one (would be more consistent)

In your example `println x[1]` does insert an entry in the map.  If you used `keySet()/entrySet()` you'd be able to iterate.  I think it's expected that by calling `get` you are ensuring that entry will be added if it does not exist already.

Of the alternatives, I think the constructor parameter might work the best so then you could construct the map like this:

`[:].withDefault(false) { 7 }`

I'd recommend opening a JIRA for this feature, hopefully that would generate some more discussion.

ok, sure, will do.

I know the `getAt` inserts it, that's why I gave it as an example - I find it confusing that a get will insert.
I would agree that if there is a new option to not store the default value, then `get` should be changed to just return the value and not add to the delegate.

... but that would be confusing also, because e.g.

``` Groovy
def x = [:].withDefault { [] }
x[1] << 0
println x // [1:[0]]
```

wouldn't work anymore
You're right, good point.  So even with the proposed change it not correct to say that the default wont be stored since it will for `get` just not `put`.

Yeah, that's why I pointed it out.
Where should I open an issue for this?

Nice change, wanted to do this myself also.
If we're changing the `with` instead (I would vote for that, as I find `doto` and `tap` unintuitive), I suggest we do the same for `each` also.

Also, please check for `NullObject` as well, as it might act as an alternative `null` check.

Btw, wouldn't it be simpler to implement it as

``` Groovy
def doto(self, closure) { self?.with(closure); self }
```

(with extension methods, of course)
@paplorinc You can open issue for groovy at https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/GROOVY
@oreissig No, It will be even better as extenstion class. I have changed my code. Thanks.
cool :-)
Testing Jenkins build for INFRA-11304.
@paulk-asert What do you think?
@blackdrag Any feedback for @shils?
@blackdrag Any feedback for @shils?
@paulk-asert What do you think?

Sorry, for not answering earlier. It might be more easy to explain by example... Look at StaticTypeCheckingVisitor.VariableExpressionTypeMemoizer. The memoizer is used in the visitor to track something, even though StaticTypeCheckingVisitor is itself a visitor. The memoizer here does a specific task, by collecting information in the subtrees of the AST, and feeds that to the original visitor. IN your case that would be the information of what bridge methods do need to be added

To answer your last question: it looks like the problem is that your delegating method calls use a variable with the delegate name as the receiver, even when the delegate is a method. In that case, the receiver should not be a variable, but rather a method call expression itself e.g. `this.getStrategy()`. Here's the block of code I'm referring to: 

``` java
MethodCallExpression mce = callX(
        alsoLazy ? propX(varX("this"), delegate.delegateName.substring(1)) :
        varX(delegate.delegateName, correctToGenericsSpecRecurse(genericsSpec, delegate.type)),
        candidate.getName(),
        args);
```
Ah, thanks a lot for pointing that one out. I mindlessly went through the class and added `delegate.` but didn't notice this variable access at all.
I completed the necessary javadoc additions and cleaned up the remaining TODOs.

Thanks for the pull request. :)

Log4j2 2.4+ requires Java 7, but groovy still supports Java 6, therefore we can not update yet.

There is already a pull request for the jline update: https://github.com/apache/groovy/pull/93 see its conversation as for why it was not merged yet.

All other updates are o.k./good I guess.
Yep, sure is.  Thanks for the PR!  :smile:
@blackdrag That's alright, I've been busier than usual as of late anyway. Thanks for the feedback, I'll take a look.

Thanks for the pull request.

Merged. Thanks! :+1:
Thank you! oh.. and +1 ;)
Thanks!

Thanks!

I guess the examples are executable? If that is the case, could you please use `<pre class="groovyTestCase">` so that they are executed during the build (like Paul did in: https://github.com/apache/groovy/commit/aa38aca0b93036453df7859de3f2a9992ab40358)?
Hi, I didn't know that appending the CSS class groovyTestCase would trigger a real test. I will add it where it is appropriate.

Thanks!

It's a well hidden feature ;) :(. 

With `<pre class="groovyTestCase">` you mark the code so that https://github.com/apache/groovy/blob/master/subprojects/groovy-test/src/main/groovy/groovy/util/JavadocAssertionTestBuilder.groovy will find it and build a test-suite. The suite is then run by https://github.com/apache/groovy/blob/master/src/test/MainJavadocAssertionTest.groovy. 

JavadocAssertionTestBuilder is distributed with Groovy, so everybody could use it, but I do not know if it is documented anywhere.
@jwagenleitner What about merging this?
Thanks! :+1:
Thanks!

...interesting.  The `Grape` modification might not be necessary.

It seems the effect we want after the `GrabCommand` gets run is a modification of the `Completer` of the `ImportCommand`.  I'm eyeing up the source of `ImportCompleter` in there... and it... seems to pass `shell` by reference.

Since we get the same `shell` when we construct `GrabCommand`, I'm going to see if we can't send a message up the chain.

@tkruse — can you take a look at my comment on 9244919 and see if it makes sense?

It seems we can specify a `classloader` to Grab without patching it.  That said— I've also been trying to modify `PackageHelper`, but it doesn't seem to have much luck getting `ImportCommand`'s completer to pick up any changes.
Thanks! Even though it is minor it is still a welcome improvement.
I would have merged this long ago if this did not modify Grape. If this modification could be removed I would merge immediately.

Yes— I _really_ think we can do this.  I've managed to get the Grab command to insert the loaded dependency in a `classloader` accessible to the `ImportCommand` completion scanner, and I've managed to get the scanner to reload its import map by sending messages.

I'm tidying up a script version of this code, and I'll post a link here.

What I _haven't_ been able to do is figure out how to test a new `Command` that I add to the `groovysh` tree: I can _build_ it, but I'm too dense to figure out how to execute the built shell. @tkruse 's work looks really good here— so it might be a matter of modifying the good work he's done.

Flipside, if someone could point me in the direction of some help testing a GroovyShell built from the core tree— I'd feel more comfortable creating one that's more appropriate to include.

I finished up a [small project](https://github.com/Dispader/groovysh-command-grab) with a simple, script-style [GrabCommand](https://github.com/Dispader/groovysh-command-grab/blob/master/src/main/groovy/GrabCommand.groovy).

The critical bit for the `classloader` is (currently) [line 40](https://github.com/Dispader/groovysh-command-grab/blob/master/src/main/groovy/GrabCommand.groovy#L40) in the method that does the grab

``` Groovy
    private void grab(String dependency) {
        Map<String, Object> dependencyMap = org.codehaus.groovy.tools.GrapeUtil.getIvyParts(dependency)
        groovy.grape.GrapeIvy grapeIvy = groovy.grape.Grape.instance
        grapeIvy.grab([classLoader: shell.interp.classLoader.parent,refObject: shell.interp], dependencyMap)
    }
```

There are still a few problems with it— notably that it toggles import completion "on", even if it's previously been set "off" intentionally.

``` Groovy
    private void reloadImportCompletion() {
        shell.packageHelper.preferenceChange(ignorePackageCompletion(true))
        shell.packageHelper.preferenceChange(ignorePackageCompletion(false))
    }
```

Anyhow, hope this helps.  I'd be happy to try to make it a Pullable command, if someone can help me understand how to execute a build shell.  But I'm wagering a more seasoned Groovy contributor could get this done faster than myself.

Cheers.

Hi Jake,

thanks for your contribution. :)

> What I haven't been able to do is figure out how to test a new Command that I add to the groovysh tree: I can build it, but I'm too dense to figure out how to execute the built shell. @tkruse 's work looks really good here— so it might be a matter of modifying the good work he's done.

I'm not sure if I understand you correctly, but you register a command by adding it to  `DefaultCommandsRegistrar` see the pull request for an example. 

Not sure if my memory is correct but then you should be able to run "org.codehaus.groovy.tools.shell.Main" from your IDE.

You can also run `./gradlew distBin` to build the distribution then unzip the zip under `target/distributions` and run the shell from there.

> But I'm wagering a more seasoned Groovy contributor could get this done faster than myself.

Thibault is the most knowledgeable. The initial creator of groovysh does not contribute anymore and the rest of the team only did a few minimal fixes/enhancements.
@Dispader It would be very nice if you could clone the repo of this pull request https://github.com/tkruse/incubator-groovy/tree/groovysh-grab and create a pull request with your updates.

@Dispader thanks for following up on this. I have been away for this weekend, and now I'm down with a cold, so I cannot think too straight.
Regarding how to start a shell with modifications, my workflow has been very messy so far:
1. I run gradle dist to create a distribution, and unzip it to some location (to have dependencies to put on the classpath).
2. I delete groovy-groovysh-$VERSION.jar from that location
3. Then I remove all groovy-based .class files left in the source dir that could be/become stale:
   `rm -rf subprojects/groovy-groovysh/target/classes/.../shell/*.class` (But NOT java-based class files)
4. Finally I run a script that starts the Main:

```
export CLASSPATH=\
subprojects/groovy-groovysh/target/classes/main:\
subprojects/groovy-groovysh/target/resources/main:\
target/classes/main:\
target/resources/main:\
.../commons-cli-1.3.1.jar:\
.../asm-5.0.3.jar:\
.../jline-2.12.jar:\
.../antlr-2.7.7.jar:\

java -classpath $CLASSPATH  org.codehaus.groovy.tools.shell.Main $@
```

This is the only way I found to be sure to run the groovy classes I am modifying against the latest java classes and latest groovysh groovy sources. Probably there is a better way, but once I got this to work, I did not bother to find that better way. Obviously it is too messy to document as recommendation.

Starting in the IDE should also work, but I usually avoid it, as I am suspicious of differences between a real command line and the IDEs command-lines.

Thanks! :+1: 

Great change, especially nice for running `gradle testSingleXYZ'.

Thanks!

Thanks for the pull request. :)

I already cherry-picked a0aed6c6e523d176ebd480075d54aa9a3e19b472 which fixes some mistakes.

I support merging the rest of the commits, although I'm not sure how much a0aed6c6e523d176ebd480075d54aa9a3e19b472 or a032ed64a21434f12d2d6a560d55c7efb79eb986 add. With 0a78058ebc415e41b9523b77a42a92b907f169f1 there is a small change that somebody calls the methods from dynamic groovy, but of course it is important to remove unused stuff.

I'm thankful for opinions of other commiters on this.

> A cycle was detected in the build path of project 'groovy'. The cycle consists of projects {groovy, groovy-ant, groovy-groovydoc, groovy-templates, groovy-xml, groovy-test, groovy-bsf, groovy-console, groovy-swing, groovy-docgenerator, groovy-groovysh, groovy-jmx, groovy-json, groovy-jsr223, groovy-macro, groovy-nio, groovy-servlet, groovy-sql, groovy-testng}

This is probably fixable, but the problem is that the groovy-eclipse compiler is a fork of the groovy compiler. Most of the time you can not compile the current code with compiler for the previous version (which the groovy-eclipse compiler always is), so having everything working in eclipse is rare. 

> build fails due to... license checks? Afraid I don't really understand what's going on with all that.

There is a gradle task which check that every source file has an apache header maybe you ran a task which uses this.

This one particular `setSize()` method in 0a78058 I actually deleted initially, but added it again when I went through the diffs and noticed the comment above. I decided to make the method @Deprecated as a neat trick to indicate in an IDE that this should not be called if written by accident. If you don't like this trick, I'll just leave the method as is.

For commit a032ed6 (avoid synthetic accessors by making private fields/methods package-private), I think removing `private` from members of private nested classes where the member is accessed by the top-level class would be ok.  However, I don't think members of top-level public classes should be changed from `private` to `package-private`.  If they weren't designed to be used by other classes in the package then they shouldn't be made visible just to avoid a synthetic method.  So overall I'd be -1 for this particular commit.

The other commits look good to me.

I also thought about the widening of scope, that may be unintended, but if there's a synthetic accessor method generated, it actually is made available inside the package anyway? Scope-wise there's not much of a difference between a package-private field and a package-private getter, or is there one?
I already found one explicit package that can be omitted here... thinking of waiting for the CI job to finish checks, closing this Pull, and making another.
Closing to clean up import.  (With many apologies.)

With apologies, I created [another Pull Request](https://github.com/apache/groovy/pull/286).  (It was the only thing I could figure out.)

@tkruse — I did give you access to my fork, so you should be able to commit/destroy/comment anything we still don't like— and you should be able to apply changes to this Pull (?).  I'm really sorry, guys— I'm still getting used to the workflow here.

Hope you're feeling better, Thibault... and I hope that I'm not annoying you or Pascal too much.

Cheers,
Jake

> but if there's a synthetic accessor method generated, it actually is made available inside the package anyway? 

To my knowledge the synthetic accessors are inserted by the Java compiler so that top-level and inner classes can access private members of each other.  From a coding perspective it is not really feasible for another class in the package to use these compiler generated accessors (i.e., they wont show up in IDE code completion).  By widening the scope of the members of the enclosing class encapsulation is being broken in order to avoid having a few synthetic accessors; the only benefit might be slight performance increase and that is even very questionable.  But many people work on the codebase and encapsulation is more important in my opinion in this context.  If someone working in the code see they can access the member they may think it was designed to be accessed by classes in the package when it actually was not.

> Scope-wise there's not much of a difference between a package-private field and a package-private getter, or is there one?

No I don't believe so.  In my original comment I was referring to synthetic accessors in general and not just those generated for methods.  I think again it comes back to encapsulation and breaking it just to avoid the synthetic accessors is not a good thing.

> Closing to clean up import. (With many apologies.)

No need to apologize.

You can also update a pull request by amending a commit and then force pushing. e.g. `commit --amend`, `push -f``.

Thanks for creating this pull request. :) 

> but doesn't suggest files as completions for :grab.

If I understand this correctly it is an advantage because you do not want files as completions for grab.

I think you should also allow the two argument grab like https://github.com/apache/groovy/pull/104/files and add a four argument version with the fourth argument being the classifier: http://docs.groovy-lang.org/latest/html/documentation/grape.html#Grape-Detail

Good point about IDEs respecting the synthetic flag, thanks! So I'll revert all the scoping changes in non-inner classes. For private inner classes the scope should not matter that much, since they as a whole are not accessible to any other classes, therefore I leave my changes there.
So shouldn't this be merged?

Rebased from trunk due to conflicts.

The only cases left where I changed from private to package-private is for private inner classes now.
